Concordancier – occurrences de « fantasy »

Contexte gauche Mot Contexte droit

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.
Content may be subject to copyright.
PERSONALITY PROCESSES AND INDIVIDUAL
DIFFERENCES
fantasy Making Learning More Fun
Louise E. Parker and Mark R. Lepper
Stanford University

For many years, master teachers have sought to create curric-
ulum units to interest and to involve their students by embed-
ding instructional materials and educational activities into ap-
fantasy bay, 1990). Underlying the use of such strategies is the common
This research was supported, in part, by Research Grant HD17371
from the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development
in motivation or of other factors.
Recent analyses by Lepper and Malone (1987; Malone &
Lepper, 1987), however, suggest one strategy—that of embed-
fantasy that theoretically should offer an effective means of enhancing
studentʼs intrinsic motivation as well as a propitious laboratory
in which to study the effects on learning of making educational
activities more intrinsically motivating for
students.

learning the material are conflicting, rather than congruent. In
cases
in which inappropriate fantasy elements com-

fantasy learning the material are conflicting, rather than congruent. In
these instances, increased motivation may actually lead to de-
creased learning.
these instances, increased motivation may actually lead to de-
creased learning.

... To improve students' performance in remembering declarative
knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom,
fantasy Incorporating fantasy literature into the curriculum shifts the
traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and
... To improve students' performance in remembering declarative
knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom,
fantasy elements serve as a powerful tool (Zuo et al., 2023).

creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and
creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
in a world that is becoming more complex (Lack & Kumar, 2003). ...

engagement in the learning process, to foster creativity and divergent
thinking among learners. Parker and Lepper (1992) demonstrated that

engagement in the learning process, to foster creativity and divergent
thinking among learners. Parker and Lepper (1992) demonstrated that

technological advancements, hectic social systems, and existential
anxieties, fantasy provides a sanctuary where we can immerse ourselves

children's motivation and learning. In an era characterized by rapid

fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

fantasy events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
(BUTTON) Show abstract
... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...
fantasy Article
Full-text available
* Feb 2025
* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and

fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried

... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...
fantasy Article
Full-text available
* Feb 2025
* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

fantasy learning the material are conflicting, rather than congruent. In

creased learning.

knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom,
fantasy Incorporating fantasy literature into the curriculum shifts the
traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and

creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
in a world that is becoming more complex (Lack & Kumar, 2003). ...

thinking among learners. Parker and Lepper (1992) demonstrated that

fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
(BUTTON) Show abstract
... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...

* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

Louise E. Parker and Mark R. Lepper

ulum units to interest and to involve their students by embed-
ding instructional materials and educational activities into ap-
fantasy bay, 1990). Underlying the use of such strategies is the common

in motivation or of other factors.

fantasy that theoretically should offer an effective means of enhancing
studentʼs intrinsic motivation as well as a propitious laboratory
in which to study the effects on learning of making educational
activities more intrinsically motivating for
students.

cases

fantasy learning the material are conflicting, rather than congruent. In
these instances, increased motivation may actually lead to de-
creased learning.

... To improve students' performance in remembering declarative
knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom,
fantasy Incorporating fantasy literature into the curriculum shifts the
traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and
... To improve students' performance in remembering declarative
knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom,
fantasy elements serve as a powerful tool (Zuo et al., 2023).

learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and
creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and
creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
in a world that is becoming more complex (Lack & Kumar, 2003). ...

engagement in the learning process, to foster creativity and divergent
thinking among learners. Parker and Lepper (1992) demonstrated that
how it can be used as a pedagogical tool to encourage students'
engagement in the learning process, to foster creativity and divergent
thinking among learners. Parker and Lepper (1992) demonstrated that

technological advancements, hectic social systems, and existential
anxieties, fantasy provides a sanctuary where we can immerse ourselves

fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
(BUTTON) Show abstract
... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...

fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...
fantasy Article
Full-text available
* Feb 2025
* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and

fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

View

fantasy events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
(BUTTON) Show abstract
... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...
fantasy Article
Full-text available
* Feb 2025
* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and

fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.
View
View
(BUTTON) Show abstract
... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
fantasy events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried

... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...

... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...
fantasy Article
Full-text available
* Feb 2025
* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and

* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

View

learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried

... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...

scores on these tasks. ...
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...
fantasy Article
Full-text available
* Feb 2025
* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

fantasy learning the material are conflicting, rather than congruent. In
these instances, increased motivation may actually lead to de-
creased learning.

knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom,

traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and

creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
in a world that is becoming more complex (Lack & Kumar, 2003). ...

2022). ...
function essential to emotional regulation has been explored in various
studies (Seja & Russ, 1999;Bacon & Charlesford, 2018;Shiota & Nomura,
2022). ...
fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...

fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...
fantasy Article
Full-text available
* Feb 2025
* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

fantasy learning the material are conflicting, rather than congruent. In
these instances, increased motivation may actually lead to de-
creased learning.

... To improve students' performance in remembering declarative

fantasy Incorporating fantasy literature into the curriculum shifts the
traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and

creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
in a world that is becoming more complex (Lack & Kumar, 2003). ...

fantasy tool and as a cognitive, creative, and cultural faculty that shapes
various aspects of human experience (Zuo et al., 2023;Shiota & Nomura,
2022;Bunce & Woolley, 2021;Richert &Schlesinger, 2022;Parker & Lepper,
tool and as a cognitive, creative, and cultural faculty that shapes
various aspects of human experience (Zuo et al., 2023;Shiota & Nomura,
2022;Bunce & Woolley, 2021;Richert &Schlesinger, 2022;Parker & Lepper,
fantasy function essential to emotional regulation has been explored in various
studies (Seja & Russ, 1999;Bacon & Charlesford, 2018;Shiota & Nomura,
2022). ...
function essential to emotional regulation has been explored in various
studies (Seja & Russ, 1999;Bacon & Charlesford, 2018;Shiota & Nomura,
2022). ...
fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...

fantasy motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults'
and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
... Although Parker and Lepper (1992) speculated that the relative
success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and
motivation (i.e., "fun"), there is a body of recent work suggesting
fantasy and children's reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015)
aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children,
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had
realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new
words in storybooks that had fantastical themes. ...
fantasy Article
Full-text available
* Feb 2025
* Deena Skolnick Weisberg Deena Skolnick Weisberg
* Donald A Saucier Donald A Saucier

fantasy fiction—but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral
sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article).
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and
the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
fantasy psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical
investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse
psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working
fantasy fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
fantasy research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs
(e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases
for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant
fantasy clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and
research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning,
clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child
and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in
fantasy highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review
illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this
construct throughout the behavioral sciences.

ArticlePDF Available

fantasyLearning More Fun

American Psychological Association
Abstract

Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
fantasy Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials
in relevant fantasy contexts on children's motivation and learning. In
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
fantasy these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts.
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational
programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with
these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract
fantasy Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical
fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after,
and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly
fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference.
Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest
and promoting learning are discussed.

fantasy learning the material are conflicting, rather than congruent. In
these instances, increased motivation may actually lead to de-
creased learning.

... To improve students' performance in remembering declarative
knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom,
fantasy Incorporating fantasy literature into the curriculum shifts the
traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and
... To improve students' performance in remembering declarative
knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom,
fantasy elements serve as a powerful tool (Zuo et al., 2023).
fantasy traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and
creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
learning (Parker & Lepper, 1992). So, fostering imagination and
creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future
in a world that is becoming more complex (Lack & Kumar, 2003). ...
fantasy how it can be used as a pedagogical tool to encourage students'
engagement in the learning process, to foster creativity and divergent
thinking among learners. Parker and Lepper (1992) demonstrated that
how it can be used as a pedagogical tool to encourage students'
engagement in the learning process, to foster creativity and divergent
thinking among learners. Parker and Lepper (1992) demonstrated that
fantasy children's motivation and learning. In an era characterized by rapid
technological advancements, hectic social systems, and existential
anxieties, fantasy provides a sanctuary where we can immerse ourselves

children's motivation and learning. In an era characterized by rapid
technological advancements, hectic social systems, and existential
fantasy in alternate realities, mythical realms, and epic adventures (Bacon &
Charlesford, 2018). ...
... The importance of fantasy in our lives lies in its profound impact
anxieties, fantasy provides a sanctuary where we can immerse ourselves
in alternate realities, mythical realms, and epic adventures (Bacon &
Charlesford, 2018). ...
fantasy on mental, emotional, and social well-being. Research conducted across
the globe highlights the multifaceted role of fantasy as a pedagogical
tool and as a cognitive, creative, and cultural faculty that shapes
Charlesford, 2018). ...
... The importance of fantasy in our lives lies in its profound impact
on mental, emotional, and social well-being. Research conducted across
fantasy tool and as a cognitive, creative, and cultural faculty that shapes
various aspects of human experience (Zuo et al., 2023;Shiota & Nomura,
2022;Bunce & Woolley, 2021;Richert &Schlesinger, 2022;Parker & Lepper,

various aspects of human experience (Zuo et al., 2023;Shiota & Nomura,
2022;Bunce & Woolley, 2021;Richert &Schlesinger, 2022;Parker & Lepper,
fantasy function essential to emotional regulation has been explored in various
studies (Seja & Russ, 1999;Bacon & Charlesford, 2018;Shiota & Nomura,
2022). ...

fantasy Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database
Article
Full-text available
* Uttam Kumar Das Uttam Kumar Das
* Ananta Kumar

fantasy bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The
PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the
Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term
fantasy shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening.
The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using
the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric
citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most
influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the
number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an
fantasy positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research
field.

... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
fantasy learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or
events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
fantasy treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy
context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
learning. For example, Parker and Lepper (1992) had children engage in
quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried
treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the
fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher
scores on these tasks. ...
